title: Basic Reflected XSS

hints.title: Understanding Reflected XSS
hints.content: Reflected XSS occurs when user input is immediately returned by the web application without proper sanitization. Look for input fields where your data gets displayed back to you.

hints.title: Basic XSS Payload
hints.content: Try injecting a simple script tag: <script>alert('XSS')</script>. This is the most basic XSS payload that executes JavaScript code.

hints.title: Alternative Payloads
hints.content: If script tags don't work, try event handlers like: or

hints.title: URL Parameter Injection
hints.content: This challenge might accept input through URL parameters. Try modifying the URL with your payload: ?name=<script>alert('XSS')</script>

hints.title: Browser Developer Tools
hints.content: Use your browser's Developer Tools (F12) to inspect the HTML source and see exactly how your input is being reflected. Look for where your payload appears in the DOM.

common_mistakes: Not URL-encoding special characters when testing in URL parameters
Trying complex payloads when simple ones work better
Not checking if the payload is actually reflected in the response
learning_objectives: Understand how reflected XSS vulnerabilities work
Learn to identify input reflection points
Use browser tools for vulnerability analysis
